titlestmt.titleproper: Ralph Rinzler papers and audio recordings, 1950-1994
titlestmt.author: Greg Adams, Rori Smith, Stephanie Smith, Jeff Place, David Walker, Stefana Breitwieser, Jennifer Nehrt, Michelina Pagliuso, Megan Northcote, Abigail Kabaker, Kimberly Stelter, James Fort, Cathy Hardman, Cecilia Peterson, Chad Kamen

publicationstmt.publisher: Ralph Rinzler Folklife Archives and Collections

address.addressline: Smithsonian Center for Folklife and Cultural Heritage

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on 2024-12-05 13:23:40 -0500.

repository.corpname: Ralph Rinzler Folklife Archives and Collections

did.unittitle: Ralph Rinzler papers and audio recordings

physdesc.extent: 87.5 cubic feet of papers, 18.82 cubic feet of audio

did.abstract: This collection, with bulk dates from 1950-1994, documents the life of Ralph Rinzler and his professional activities as Director of Field Programs for the Newport Folk Festival, Director of the Smithsonian Folklife Festival (formerly the Festival of American Folklife) and the Office of Folklife Programs (now the Center for Folklife and Cultural Heritage), and the Smithsonian Institution's Assistant Secretary for Public Service. Includes personal papers, business records, correspondence, notes, photographs, audiotapes and field recordings.

bioghist.head: Biographical/Historical note
bioghist.p: Ralph Rinzler (1934-1994) was born in Passaic, New Jersey, and was interested in music at an early age. He was given a collection of ethnographic recordings from the Archive of Folk Song of the Library of Congress by his uncle, Harvard University ballad scholar George Lyman Kittredge, and they soon became his favorites. He became actively involved in the Folk Revival while attending Swarthmore College, organizing an annual festival on campus. He received his B.A. in 1956, and did graduate work at Middlebury College and the Sorbonne in French literature and language. Upon his return to the United States, he played mandolin for four years with the Greenbriar Boys, at times touring with singer Joan Baez. During the 1960s, he also studied, recorded, and worked with performers of traditional music, such as Doc Watson and Bill Monroe, both of whom gained international recognition in part through his efforts. In 1964, Rinzler accepted the position of Director of Field Programs at the Newport Folk Foundation, which involved the planning and programming of the Newport Folk Festival.

Rinzler came to the Smithsonian in 1967 as co-founder of the Festival of American Folklife (now the Smithsonian Folklife Festival) with James Morris in what was then the Smithsonian's Division of Performing Arts. After the 1976 Bicentennial Festival, Rinzler became the founding director of the Office of Folklife Programs (now the Center for Folklife and Cultural Heritage) to establish a center for research, publication, and presentation of programs in American culture and tradition. As Director, he initiated Smithsonian Folklife Studies, a publication series, and did research for the Celebration exhibit, which opened at the Renwick Gallery in 1982. Rinzler was appointed Assistant Secretary for Public Service in 1983 and Assistant Secretary Emeritus in 1990. Ralph Rinzler died on July 2, 1994.

arrangement.head: Arrangement note
arrangement.p: The collection is currently arranged in 9 archival series as follows:

The papers and photographs contained in the first 8 series are processed at an intermediate level, which means that all material was rehoused in archival folders, with folder-level arrangements and descriptions. Individual items within folders may not be fully arranged or described, due to the collection's level of complexity when it was deposited in the Archives.
When possible, folders were arranged alphabetically within series and subseries.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access note
accessrestrict.p: Access to the Ralph Rinzler Folklife Archives and Collections is by appointment only. Visit our website for more information on scheduling a visit or making a digitization request. Researchers interested in accessing born-digital records or audiovisual recordings in this collection must use access copies.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use note
userestrict.p: Permission to publish materials from the collection must be requested from the Ralph Rinzler Folklife Archives and Collections. Please visit our website to learn more about submitting a request. The Ralph Rinzler Folklife Archives and Collections make no guarantees concerning copyright or other intellectual property restrictions. Other usage conditions may apply; please see the Smithsonian's Terms of Use for more information.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Ralph Rinzler papers and audio recordings, Ralph Rinzler Folklife Archives and Collections, Smithsonian Institution.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: The Rinzler Papers did not arrive in the Archives with any discernible original order. For many years, a preliminary inventory was the only access point to the papers. Since August 2011, a significant amount of survey and analytical work allowed archivists to impose order across nearly all of the papers. With the resulting folder-level arrangement across each series and subseries, many of the folders are accompanied by scope and content notes.
In the spring of 2021, the collection and its accompanying finding aid were revisited and further refined.
Processing remains ongoing for oversize materials (as of May 2021).

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: The materials in this collection were deposited into the archives of the Center for Folklife and Cultural Heritage over a number of years by Ralph Rinzler, Kate Rinzler, and Jeff Place in honor of the aforementioned. From the 1980s until Ralph Rinzler's passing in 1994, the Center received the majority of the audio tapes and photographs in this collection directly from Rinzler. With Rinzler's death in 1994, Jeff Place reviewed and deposited the majority of Rinzler's papers at the Center.

Until her passing in 2011, Kate Rinzler donated materials to this collection, with more continuing to arrive via her estate (as of May 2021). Many of these items were rehoused in the Kate Rinzler Papers.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Ralph Rinzler Papers and Audio Recordings encompasses a wide range of materials from Rinzler's prolific personal and professional life. Predominantly consisting of clippings, collected texts, correspondence, meeting notes, photographs, and production materials, this collection charts Rinzler's role in the mid-twentieth century emergence of community-based and institutional efforts to preserve, sustain, and amplify cultural heritage. As an assemblage of materials from all aspects of his life, the Ralph Rinzler Papers also reflect the many integral relationships he developed throughout the years with his colleagues, contemporaries, family, and friends.

odd.head: Shared Stewardship of Collections
odd.p: The Center for Folklife and Cultural Heritage acknowledges and respects the right of artists, performers, Folklife Festival participants, community-based scholars, and knowledge-keepers to collaboratively steward representations of themselves and their intangible cultural heritage in media produced, curated, and distributed by the Center. Making this collection accessible to the public is an ongoing process grounded in the Center's commitment to connecting living people and cultures to the materials this collection represents. To view the Center's full shared stewardship policy, which defines our protocols for addressing collections-related inquiries and concerns, please visit https://doi.org/10.25573/data.21771155.

did.unittitle: Audio

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series consists of the audio recordings related to Ralph Rinzler's life and career. The files are arranged by format in three subseries groups as follows:
1. Open Reel Tapes
2. Instantaneous Discs
3. Compact Audio Cassettes

did.unittitle: Uncle Wade - A Memorial to Wade Ward: Old Time Virginia Banjo Picker, 1892-1971

scopecontent.head: Contents
scopecontent.p: Conversation with Granny Porter ; Cluck old hen (1:27) -- Western country ; Katy Hill ; Reminiscences ; Old Jimmy Sutton (7:43) --Black Mountain rag (2:02) --Polly put the kettle on (0:55) --Ida Red (1:21) --John Lover is gone (2:25) -- Conversation with Wade Ward and Glen Smith ; AR[kansas] traveler ; Katy Hill (3:55) --Foxchase (1: 20) --Chlly winds (1:06) --Half-shaved (1:05) --Old Reuben (1:12) --June apple (0:55) --Mississippi sawyer (1:24) --Katy Hill ; Reminiscences ; Billy in the lowground (3:06) --Nancy Blevins (1:21) --Sourwood Mountain (1:52) --Chicken reel (1:44) --Ragtime Annie (2 :24) --Katy Hill's reminiscences ; Sally Goodin' (3:28) --Sally Ann (2:00) --Old Joe Clark ; Reminiscences ; Peace Bottom Creek (4:39) --Lone prairie (0:54).

scopecontent.head: Contents
scopecontent.p: 1. Emmet Miller, Narmour & Smith, Fiddlin' John Carson, Moonshine Kate, Bud Blue, Frank Hutcheson, Black Brothers, Martin Malloy- The Medicine Show Part 1 & 2 (OK 45380) 2. The Medicine Show Part 3 (OK 45391) 3. The Medicine Show Part 4 (OK 45391) 4. Charlie Monroe and His Kentucky Pardners- Red Rocking Chair (VI 210145) 5. Earl Johnson's Dixie Entertainers- He's a Beaut (VI 23638A) 6. E.J.D.E.- I Lost My Girl (VI 23638B) 7. E.J.D.E.- Rocky Palace (VI 40304B) 8. E.J.D.E.- Green Mountain Polka (VI 40304B) 9. Earl Johnson And His Clodhoppers- They Don't Roost to High For Me (OK 45223) 10. E.J.D.E.- Mississippi Jubilee (OK 45223) 11. Harlan Miner's Fiddlers- Sugar In My Coffee (MW 3023A) 12. Frank Hutchison- Worried Blues (OK 45114) 13. Frank Hutchison- the Train That Carried the Girl From Town (OK 45114) 14. The Hawking Brothers.- I'll Move On (RE G25421) 15. Grandpa Jones and the Delmore Brothers.- Darbys Ram (KI 708A) 16. Blind Willie Johnson- Jesus Is Coming (JA 527) 17. Blind Willie Johnson- The City of Refuge (JA 527) 18. Grandpa Jones- Jonah and the Whale (KI 815AA) 19. Blind Willie Johnson- Dark Was the Night (JA 512A) 20. Blind Willie Johnson- Nobody's Fault But Mine (JA 512B) 21. Grandpa Jones- Are You from Dixie (KI 847A 22. Grandpa Jones- Jesse James (KI 847A) 23. Fred Kirby's Carolina Boys- Deep Sea Blues (DE 5708B) 24. Buell Kazee- Rock Island (BR 145A) 25. Jerry Jordan- Old Johnny Bucker Won't Do (SU 9407B) 26. Jerry Jordan- The Cats Got the Measles the Dogs Got the Whooping Cough (SU 9407A) 27. Herman the Hermit- Hitler Lives (CA 421) 1. Grandpa Jones- 144 Thousand Were There (KI 474A) 2. Earl Johnson and His Clodhoppers- Nigger on the Woodpile (OK 45264) 3. Buell Kazee- A Mountain Boy Makes His First Record Part 1 (BR 338) 4. A Mountain Boy Makes His First Record Part 2 (BR 338) 5. Alfred G. Karnes- I am Bound For the Promised Land (VI 20840A) 6. Alfred G. Karnes- We Shall All be Reunited (VI 40076) 7. Kessinger Brothers- Sourwood Mountain (BR 308) 8. Kessinger Brothers- Sally Goodin (BR 308) 9. Kessinger Brothers- Chicken In the Barnyard (BR 256) 10. Kessinger Brothers- Devil's Dream (BR 256) 11. Kessinger Brothers- Sopping the Gravy (BR 411) 12. Kessinger Brothers- Don't Let the Deal Go Down (BR 411) 13. Kessinger Brothers- Chinky Pin (BR 396) 14. Kessinger Brothers- Done Gone (BR 396) 15. Kessinger Brothers- Sixteen Days I Let Behind Me (BR 267) 16. Kessinger Brothers- The Girl I Left Behind Me (BR 267) 17. Fred Kirby's Carolina Boys- Birmingham Jail (DE 5576A) 18. Fred Kirby's Carolina Boys- Columbus Stockade Blues (DE 5576A) 19. Bela Larn and His Green County Singers- May, Dearest May (OK 45136) 20. Bela Larn- Poor Little Bennie (OK 45136) 21. scopecontent.p: 1. Frank Hutchison- The Miners Blues (OK 45258) 2. Frank Hutchison- K.C. Blues (OK 45452) 3. J.H. Howells Carolina Hillbillies- Girl That Worries My Mind (BB 8219B) 4. John Henry Howard- Gonna Keep My Skillet Good and Greasy (GE 3124B) 5. H. Martin, H. Roberts- Crawdad Song (ME 13148B) 6. Asa Martin, Ray Hobbs- Hot Corn (CH 45065A) 7. George Holden- Preacher and the Bear (CH 392A) 8. George Holden- The Marion Parker Murder (CH 385D) 9. George Holden- The Sinking Of the Submarine S-4 (CH 385B) 10. Earl Shirkey, Roy Harper- The Virginia Strike of '23 (CO 15535D) 11. Uncle Henry's Original Kent. Mount.- Swing Me Ladies Up and Down (CA 48037) 12. Sid Hampton- Kicking Mule (CO 15555D) 13. AL Hopkins and his Buckle Busters- Buck Eyed Rabbits (BR 104A) 14. Roy Harvey, Leonard Copeland- Bakley Rag (CO 15514D) 15. Roy Harvey, Leonard Copeland- Just Pickin (CO 15514D) 16. The Home Town Boys- Home Town Rag (CO 15762D) 17. The Home Town Boys- Raccoon On a Rail (CO 15762D) 18. Al Hopkins and His Buckle Busters- Cluck Old Hen (BR 0095A) 19. Al Hopkins- Black Eyed Susie (BR 80095B) 20. J.H. Howells Carolina Hillbillies- Lonesome Life of Worry (BB 8236B) 21. Al Hopkins- Roll On the Ground (BR 186B) 22. Al Hopkins- Ride That Mule (BR 186A) 23. Wm. B. Houchens- Arkansas Traveler (GE 4974A) 24. Wm. B. Houcnens- Turkey In the Straw (GE 4974B) 25. Al Hopkins- Bug in the Taters (BR 182A) 26. Al Hopkins- Beatin Up Sandy (BR 182A) 27. Hobbs Brothers- Hell Among the Yearlings (BA 6224B) 1. The Highlanders- Richmond Square (PA3184B) 2. Bill Helmes and His Upson City Band- Thomastown Breakdown (VI 1649B) 3. Bill Helmes- Georgia Blues (VI 21649A) 4. Kenawhow Singers- Golden Slippers (VO A5173) 5. The Hill Billies- Hear Dem Bells (VO B5173) 6. Willard Hodgin- Don't Get One Woman On Your Mind (VI 21485B) 7. Lake Howard- I Have No One to Love Me (ME 13426B) 8. Lake Howard- It's None of Your Business (ME 13426A) 9. Roy Harvey, Leonard Copeland- Underneath the Sugar Moon (CO 15582D) 10. Roy Harvey, Leonard Copeland- Lonesome Weary Blues (CO 15582D) 11. Len and Joe Higgins- Slippery Elm Tree (CO 15354D) 12. Sim Harns- Pass Around the Bottle (OR 916) 13. Sim Harns- Hand Me Down My Walking Cane (OR 916) 14. Kelly Harrell- Charlie, He's a Good Old Man (VI 21069B) 15. Kelly Harrell- For Seven Long Years I've Been Married (VI 21069B) 16. Kelly Harrell- My Wife She Has Come and Gone And Left Me (VI 21520) 17. Ed Helton Singers- A Storm on the Sea (CO 15327D) 18. Ed Helton Singers- My Old Cottage Home (CO 15327D) 19. Hawkshaw Hawkins- Pan American (KI 689A) 20. Charlie Herald and His Roundup Rangers- Circassium Circle (BB 4975B) 21. Charlie Herald- White Cockade (BB 4975A) 22. Charlie Herald- The Wind That Shakes the Barley (BB 4963A) 23. Charlie Herlad- Swallow Tail Jig (BB 4963B) 24. Harkins, Moran- In the Sweet Bye and Bye (BW 8117B) 25. Harkins, Moran- Way Down in Jail On My Knees (BW 8115A) 26. Harper, Turner- Life's a Railway To Heaven (SU 9658A) 27. Frank Hutchison- Hutchison's Rag (OK 45274) 28. Uncle Jim Hawkins- All I've Got Is Done Gone (CH 111B) 29. Fiddlin Dave Neal- Seneca Square Dance (CH 301B)

did.unittitle: Rinzler Fieldwork: Bill Monroe and the Blue Grass Boys, Evening Concert, Brown County Jamboree

scopecontent.head: Contents
scopecontent.p: CD 1- Forgotten soldier boy--All the good times are passed and gone--Let us be lovers again--On my way back home--Pearly gates--I'm rolling on--Little Joe--My long journey home--Nine pound hammer--Banks of the Ohio (Dave Macon)--Lonesome valley--God holds the future in his hands--Were you there?--Shake my mother's hand; Brown County Jamboree--Big Sandy--Can't you hear me calling--Y'all come; other Brown County show--Intro--Bile them cabbage down--I ain't broke but I'm badly bent--I hope you learned--Bugle call rag--Y'all come--Changing partners--Blue moon of Kentucky--Get up John; CD2-- Down yonder--A little talk with Jesus--Boat of love--I hear a sweet voice calling--Girl in the blue velvet band--White House blues--My rose of Kentucky--Uncle Pen--Rock road blues (frag)--Rocky road blues--First whipporwill--Little girl and the dreadful snake--I'm knocking at your door--He will set your fields on fire

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: Restrictions on access. Some duplication is allowed. Use of materials needs permission of the Smithsonian Institution.

odd.head: General
odd.p: Wilgus collection of Monroe 78's and two shows with the Blue Grass Boys, Bean Blossom Indiana, June 2, 1963 and September 19, 1954
